sections.introduction:
A planar straight line graph Î“Î“\Gamma
(or PSLG from now on) is the
disjoint union of a finite number
(possibly none) of non-intersecting
open line segments (called the edges of Î“Î“\Gamma)
together with a disjoint finite point set (the vertices
of Î“Î“\Gamma)
that includes all the endpoints of the line segments,
but may include other points as well. If Vğ‘‰V is a finite point set in the plane,
a triangulation of Vğ‘‰V is a PSLG with vertex
set Vğ‘‰V and a maximal set of edges.
If Î“Î“\Gamma is a PSLG with vertex set
Vğ‘‰V, then a conforming triangulation for
Î“Î“\Gamma is a triangulation of a point
set Vâ€²superscriptğ‘‰â€²V^{\prime} that contains Vğ‘‰V and such that
the union of the vertices and edges of the triangulation
covers Î“Î“\Gamma. We allow Vâ€²superscriptğ‘‰â€²V^{\prime} to be strictly
larger than Vğ‘‰V; in this case Vâ€²âˆ–Vsuperscriptğ‘‰â€²ğ‘‰V^{\prime}\setminus V are
called the Steiner points.
We want to build conforming triangulations
for Î“Î“\Gamma that have small
complexity (the number of triangles used)
and good geometry (the shape
of each triangle; no angles too large or too small),
but these two goals are often in conflict.
In this paper, we are interested in finding the best
angle bounds on the triangles that allow us to
polynomially bound the number of triangles needed
in terms of nğ‘›n, the number of vertices of Î“Î“\Gamma. If we triangulate a 1Ã—r1ğ‘Ÿ1\times r rectangle into a fixed
number of elements, it is easy to check that some angles
must tend to zero as râ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘Ÿr\to\infty, so there is
no uniform, strictly positive lower angle bound possible,
if we want
the number of triangles to be bounded only in
terms of the number of vertices of the given PSLG.
Since the angles
of a triangle sum to 180âˆ˜superscript180180^{\circ}, if we had an upper
bound of 90âˆ˜âˆ’Ïµsuperscript90italic-Ïµ90^{\circ}-\epsilon on the angles of
a triangulation, then we also have a 2â€‹Ïµ2italic-Ïµ2\epsilon lower
angle bound.
Therefore, no upper bound strictly less than 90âˆ˜superscript9090^{\circ}
is possible.
Thus nonobtuse triangulation
(all angles â‰¤90âˆ˜absentsuperscript90\leq 90^{\circ}) is the
best we can hope for. In 1960 Burago and Zalgaller  showed that any polyhedral
surface has an acute triangulation
(all angles <90âˆ˜absentsuperscript90<90^{\circ}),
but without giving a bound on
the number of triangles needed. This was used as a technical
lemma in their proof of a polyhedral version of the Nash embedding
theorem.
In 1984 Gerver 
used the Riemann mapping theorem to show that if a polygonâ€™s
angles all exceed 36âˆ˜superscript3636^{\circ}, then there
exists a dissection of it into triangles with maximum angle 72âˆ˜superscript7272^{\circ} (in
a dissection, adjacent triangles need not meet along an entire
edge).
In 1988 Baker, Grosse and Rafferty 
again proved that any polygon has a nonobtuse triangulation,
and their construction also gives a lower
angle bound. As noted above, in this case no complexity
bound in terms of nğ‘›n
alone is possible, although there is a sharp bound in terms of
integrating the local feature size over the polygon.
For details, see
,

or the survey . A linear bound for nonobtuse triangulation of point sets was given
by Bern, Eppstein and Gilbert ,
and Bern and Eppstein  gave a quadratic
bound for simple polygons with holes
(this is a polygonal region where every boundary component
is a simple closed curve or an
isolated point). Bern, Dobkin and Eppstein  improved this
to Oâ€‹(n1.85)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›1.85O(n^{1.85}) for convex domains.
Bern, S. Mitchell and Ruppert
 gave a Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) algorithm for nonobtuse
triangulation of simple polygons with holes in 1994 and
their construction uses only right triangles.
We shall make use of their result in this paper.
These and related results are discussed in the surveys
 and 0.
Other papers that deal with algorithms for finding nonobtuse
and acute triangulations include
0,
,
,
and .
Giving a polynomial upper bound for the
complexity of
nonobtuse triangulation of PSLGs has remained open
(e.g., see Problem 3 of ).
We give such a bound by proving: Every PSLG with nğ‘›n vertices
has a Oâ€‹(n2.5)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2.5O(n^{2.5}) conforming nonobtuse triangulation. Maehara  showed that any
nonobtuse triangulation
using Nğ‘N triangles can be refined to an
acute triangulation (all angles <90âˆ˜absentsuperscript90<90^{\circ})
with Oâ€‹(N)ğ‘‚ğ‘O(N) elements.
A different proof was given by
Yuan 5.
In our proof of Theorem 1.1 the triangulation
will consist of all right triangles, but the arguments of
Maehara or Yuan then show the theorem also holds with
an acute triangulation, at the cost of a
larger constant in the Oâ€‹(n2.5)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2.5O(n^{2.5}).
As noted above, simple examples
give a quadratic lower bound for PSLGs (see ),
so a gap remains between
our upper bound and the worst known example.
However, this gap can be eliminated in some special cases, e.g., A triangulation of a simple nğ‘›n-gon has a
Oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2O(n^{2}) nonobtuse refinement. This improves a Oâ€‹(n4)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›4O(n^{4}) bound given by Bern and Eppstein
.
We can also approach the quadratic lower bound
if we consider â€œalmost nonobtuseâ€ triangulations: Suppose Î¸>0ğœƒ0\theta>0.
Every PSLG with nğ‘›n vertices has a conforming
triangulation with
Oâ€‹(n2/Î¸2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2superscriptğœƒ2O(n^{2}/\theta^{2}) elements and all angles
â‰¤90âˆ˜+Î¸absentsuperscript90ğœƒ\leq 90^{\circ}+\theta. This improves a result of S. Mitchell 
with upper angle bound
78â€‹Ï€=157.5âˆ˜78ğœ‹superscript157.5\frac{7}{8}\pi=157.5^{\circ} and a result of Tan 7 with
1115â€‹Ï€=132âˆ˜1115ğœ‹superscript132\frac{11}{15}\pi=132^{\circ}. A triangulation is called Delaunay if whenever two triangles
share an edge eğ‘’e, the two angles opposite eğ‘’e sum to 180âˆ˜superscript180180^{\circ}
or less. If all the triangles are nonobtuse, then this is certainly the
case, so Theorem 1.1 immediate implies Every PSLG with nğ‘›n vertices
has a Oâ€‹(n2.5)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2.5O(n^{2.5}) conforming Delaunay triangulation. This improves a 1993 result of Edelsbrunner and Tan 
that any PSLG has a conforming Delaunay
triangulation of size Oâ€‹(n3)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›3O(n^{3}).
Conforming Delaunay triangulations for Î“Î“\Gamma
are also called Delaunay
refinements of Î“Î“\Gamma. There are numerous papers discussing
Delaunay refinements including
,
1,
,
,
1
and
5.
The argument in this paper does not seem to
give a better estimate for Delaunay triangulations
than for nonobtuse triangulations, nor does the proof
appear to simplify in the Delaunay case.
Finding an improvement (either for the estimate
or the argument) in the Delaunay case would be
extremely interesting. An alternative formulation of the Delaunay condition is that
every edge in the triangulation is the chord of an open disk
that contains no vertices of the triangulation. We say the
triangulation is Gabriel if every edge is the diameter
of such disk. It is easy to check that a nonobtuse triangulation
must be Gabriel, so we also obtain a stronger version of the
previous corollary: Every PSLG with nğ‘›n vertices
has a Oâ€‹(n2.5)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2.5O(n^{2.5}) conforming Gabriel triangulation. Given a finite planar point set Vğ‘‰V, and a point
vâˆˆVğ‘£ğ‘‰v\in V, the Voronoi cell corresponding to vğ‘£v is
the open set of points that are strictly closer to
vğ‘£v than to any other point of Vğ‘‰V. The union of the
boundaries of the all the Voronoi cells is called
the Voronoi diagram of Vğ‘‰V.
In 2, it is shown that given a nonobtuse
triangulation with Nğ‘N elements, one can find a set of Oâ€‹(N)ğ‘‚ğ‘O(N)
points so that the Voronoi diagram of the point set covers
all the edges of the triangulation. Thus we obtain For every PSLG Î“Î“\Gamma with nğ‘›n vertices, there is a point
set Sğ‘†S of size Oâ€‹(n2.5)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2.5O(n^{2.5}) whose Voronoi diagram covers Î“Î“\Gamma. The authors of 2 were interested in a type of
machine learning called â€œnearest neighbor learningâ€.
Given Î“Î“\Gamma and Sğ‘†S as in the corollary, and any point
zğ‘§z in the plane,
we can decide which complementary component
of Î“Î“\Gamma zğ‘§z belongs to by finding the
element wğ‘¤w of Sğ‘†S that is closest to zğ‘§z; zğ‘§z and wğ‘¤w must
belong to the same complementary component of Î“Î“\Gamma.
Thus the corollary
says that a partition of the
plane by a PSLG of size nğ‘›n can be â€œlearnedâ€ from a point
set of size Oâ€‹(n2.5)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2.5O(n^{2.5}). This answers a question from
2 asking if a polynomial number of points
always suffices. Acute and nonobtuse triangulations arise in a variety
of other contexts. In recreational
mathematics one asks for the smallest
triangulation of a given object into acute
or nonobtuse pieces. For example, a square can obviously be
meshed with two right triangles, but less obvious is the
fact that it can be acutely triangulated
with eight elements but not seven; see .
For further results of this type see
3,
4,
6,
7,
8,
9,
,
,
3,
6,
7,
8,
the 2002 survey 0 and
the 2010 survey 9.
There is less known in higher dimensions, but
recent work has shown
there is an acute triangulation of â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3},
but no acute triangulation
of â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n}, nâ‰¥4ğ‘›4n\geq 4
,
,
,
0,
1,
2.
Finding polynomial bounds for conforming Delaunay tetrahedral meshes
in higher dimensions remains open. In various numerical methods involving meshes,
a nonobtuse triangulation
frequently gives simpler and better behaved algorithms.
For example, in 4
Vavasis bounds various matrix norms arising from
the finite element method in terms of the number nğ‘›n
of triangulation elements; for general
triangulations his estimate is exponential in nğ‘›n, but for nonobtuse
triangulations it is only linear in nğ‘›n.
Other examples where nonobtuse or Delaunay triangulations give
simpler or faster methods include:
discrete maximum principles
,
,
3;
Stieltjes matrices in finite element methods
,
6;
convenient description of the dual graph ;
the Hamilton-Jacobi equation ;
the fast marching method 4;
the tent pitcher algorithm for meshing space-time
,
8,
9. The ideas in this paper are used in a companion paper
1
to obtain conforming quadrilateral meshes for PSLGs
that have optimal angle
bounds and optimal worst case complexity.
The precise statement from this paper used in
1 is Lemma 13.1;
this follows from a slight modification of
the proof of Theorem 1.3.
The result obtained in 1 says
that every PSLG has an Oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2O(n^{2}) conforming quadrilateral mesh with
all angles â‰¤120âˆ˜absentsuperscript120\leq 120^{\circ} and
all new angles â‰¥60âˆ˜absentsuperscript60\geq 60^{\circ}.
The angle bounds and
quadratic complexity bound are both sharp. Many thanks to Joe Mitchell and Estie Arkin for numerous
conversations about computational geometry in general and
the results of this paper in particular. Also thanks to two
anonymous referees for many helpful comments and suggestions
on two earlier versions of the paper; their efforts
greatly improved the presentation in this version. In Section 2 we recall a theorem of
Bern, Mitchell and Ruppert  that connects
nonobtuse triangulation to finding Gabriel edges, and
we sketch the proof of this result in Section 3.
In Section 4 we use their theorem to give a simple
proof of Theorem 1.2. In
Sections 5-8
we discuss propagation paths,
dissections and return regions; these are used in
the proofs of both Theorems 1.1 and 1.3.
Sections 9â€“12
give the proof of Theorem
1.3 and Section 13
summarizes facts
from the proof that are used in the sequel paper
1. Section 14 gives an
overview of the proof of Theorem 1.1
and Sections 15â€“21 provide the details.
